Trackers don’t drain too much energy but their cost and cost to maintain doesn’t generally pay off.  I designed these mounts so I can manually adjust them for the seasons, and so I can orient them vertically when it snows.
I designed them and engineered them for snow and wind loads. When I get time to draw them up properly, I might put the plans on the internet.  It’s a very simple design.
The next panels I add will face east and west, because solar panels are cheap and it’s cheaper to do that at my scale than to maintain a mechanical tracker.

(1) conclusions from US temperature data set can only be strictly applied to the US, (eg. US might not be warming over that period)

but

(2) the world data set includes the US data set, and relies on it due to sparse data from that period of time from other parts of the globe.
☝️Every hour, like clockwork.

🙏 That was exactly my point. I contemplated calling poli-sci a quasi-science instead of a pseudo-science, but the scientifically illiterate would have thought that I was talking about quasars or quarks or Quasimodo. But the goal was achieved: Kerry said it wasn’t science.

I don’t think the author of the video means to imply that “as goes the U.S., so goes the whole planet.” He’s pointing out that the RAW U.S. temperature data is considered the best available data for the early part of the century and has been used by others to make conclusions.
